subject: Re: [junit] Is it possible to include javadoc/comments in junitreports?
msgSnippet: I have found that the best way to do this is probably with one s own TestListener instance. I found the facilities for pointing junit at a bunch of packages
messageBody:
I have found that the best way to do this is probably with one's own
TestListener instance.

I found the facilities for pointing junit at a bunch of packages and
having it figure out which tests to run to be problematic. It was just
too fragile, and every time I set things up I got that annoying error
about the classpath, which seems to be saying "it is your fault, and
you're an idiot, so don't bother us". Once I made my own test suite as
a static instance, managed the TestResult object myself and added a
TestListener instance, a whole bunch of this stuff became much, much
easier.

Including this.

The TestListener instance has access to every test as it is run. So, at
that point, you can have something you log, however much of it you
want. One can even have an external source of information at that
point. We have a database of our tests and I can query that in the
TestListener and annotate the results with whatever stuff I want.

I frankly do not know whether junitreport can do these things. But it
just puts out html. I can do that well enough myself, once i have the
information.

- ray

On Aug 16, 2004, at 9:44 AM, valerie_abelin wrote:

> I'm using Ant to run junit and junitreport.  I like the HTML output
> that junitreport generates, but I am wondering if it is possible to
> include more javadoc/comments in the output rather than just the
> success/failure status and time the test took to run.  It would be
> great if junitreport could include a comment from the source code
> about what each test means.
>
